Award.AwardTitle: Development of an Asymptotically-Reduced, Multiscale Model of Turbulent Boundary Layer Dynamics at Extreme Reynolds Numbers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1437851
Chini, Gregory


The goal of the proposed study is to use a combination of theory and unique experiments to develop a new approach to modeling turbulent flows in the boundary layer. The capacity to understand, predict, and control turbulent boundary layer dynamics is important for a multitude of technological applications and scientifically important processes. Turbulence is prevalent in the world we live in and in the industry. Success in this research could impact any industrial process that involves turbulent flow, with consequent societal benefits in the form of new products, improved energy efficiency, quieter systems, etc. Problems related to geophysical and astrophysical flows could also be approached in a new, more accurate way. The educational plan involves the participation of both graduate and undergraduate students.

The main goal of the proposed research is to develop a multiscale Partial Differential Equation (PDE) model of turbulent boundary layer dynamics through the integrated useof high Reynolds number (Re) asymptotics and well-resolved high-Re experiments. By its very nature, the model development process will elucidate the so-called "inner/outer" interaction, as these are linked to boundary layer evolution as Re tends to infinity. In addition, numerical solutions of the multiscale PDEs promise to be less costly than direct numerical simulations (DNS) of the primitive Navier?Stokes (NS) equations from which they are derived, thereby enabling simulations in otherwise inaccessible parameter regimes. The proposed model will be distinct from other recent efforts, because the model retains a first principles foundation, with no reliance on system inputs or phenomenological assumptions. The multiscale analysis on which the model is based brings together recent advances in the asymptotic analysis of turbulent geophysical flows, of "exact coherent structures" in high-Re shear flows, and of the mean dynamics in canonical turbulent wall-flows. The target model is a closed multiscale PDE system that is self-consistently and systematically simplified relative to the primitive NS equations. This critical scaling information is only accessible through well-resolved, high-Re experiments. In this regard, the Univ. of New Hampshire Flow Physics Facility (FPF), which is the world's largest flow physics quality boundary layer wind tunnel, allows high-resolution measurements of velocity and vorticity at extreme Reynolds numbers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The turbulent or seemingly random motion of fluids (i.e., liquids and gases) past solid surfaces and other boundaries is pervasive in both Nature and technology.  These so-called turbulent wall flows control, e.g., the drag on automobiles, ships, and aircraft; the cooling of electronic components; and the transfer of heat and carbon dioxide between the oceans and atmosphere.  Quantitative prediction and understanding of boundary-driven turbulence is, therefore, crucial for addressing a host of societal challenges ranging from energy efficiency to environmental sustainability and climate change.  

Although the Navier--Stokes (NS) equations (a version of Newton's second law) governing fluid motion have been known for over 100 years, turbulent flows are so complex that relevant analytical solutions to these equations are not feasible, and recourse must be had to computer simulations.  Even with modern supercomputers, however, simulations in realistic parameter regimes generally remain out of reach in many applications. Accordingly, in this NSF-funded project, a team of researchers from the University of New Hampshire (UNH) has employed a synergistic complement of laboratory experiments -- making use of the UNH Flow Physics Facility, the largest flow-physics quality low-speed wind tunnel in the world -- and sophisticated mathematical analyses to investigate the fundamental physics of turbulence near boundaries.  

Through this project, the UNH research team has provided a strong empirical and theoretical basis for a new paradigm of turbulent wall flows.  According to this paradigm, the turbulence spontaneously self-organizes into a hierarchical arrangement of counter-rotating streamwise roll motions that differentially homogenize the momentum of the streamwise flow, leading to staircase-like profiles of streamwise velocity (see figure 1). Using advanced mathematical techniques, the UNH researchers were able to derive directly from the governing NS equations a novel self-sustaining process (SSP) theory that explains the formation and sustenance of these non-smooth velocity profiles---a primary project outcome.  Specifically, their SSP theory demonstrates that the nonlinear interaction among instability waves within the shear layers that form the steps of the staircase is capable of forcing roll motions that, in turn, induce the staircase-like profiles of streamwise velocity (see figure 2).  Moreover, by exploiting this spontaneous self-organization, the research team has provided a mathematically-sound basis for new, more efficient numerical algorithms for computer simulations of turbulent wall flows.  A further synergistic project outcome achieved by the team is the construction of a simplified, one-dimensional turbulence model that captures key statistics of these flows (see figure 3).  These various research outcomes are summarized in 12 peer-reviewed scientific papers that the UNH researchers published in premier fluid dynamics journals during the course of this NSF-funded project.  Finally, the project has provided advanced training in STEM-related disciplines for three Ph.D. students (including one female) and two undergraduate research assistants.  Through their collective efforts on the project, the UNH team continues to lead research into the fundamental physical mechanisms controlling turbulent wall flows.
